text: [THEME MUSIC]

ALISON BEARD: Welcome
to the HBR IdeaCast
from Harvard Business Review.
I'm Alison Beard.
[THEME MUSIC]

In 1967, my guest
today and a few friends

published the first
issue of a new magazine.

[BOB DYLAN, "LIKE A ROLLING
 STONE"] How does it feel to be

without a home, like a complete
unknown, like a rolling stone?

Rolling Stone changed
music journalism

because it covered rock and
roll and other emerging genres
seriously.

It also shifted the way
politics and social issues

were covered in America
and eventually abroad

through its foreign editions
with embedded reporting

and innovative writing
on war, elections,
drug use, and the environment.

Its founding editor and
publisher, Jann Wenner,

spent five decades at its home,
cultivating an impressive crew

of editors, designers,
and photographers

from Hunter Thompson
to Annie Leibovitz.

He also featured
and befriended some

of the biggest names in music
from Bob Dylan, whose song you

just heard, to The Beatles,
Bruce Springsteen, and Bono.

His new memoir chronicles
that whole history.

And you'll find more
of our conversation

in the November/December issue
of HBR and soon on hbr.org.

But for this
interview, we're going

to focus mainly on spotting
and managing creative talent.

Jann, it's great to
have you on the show.

JANN WENNER: Thank
you very much.
[THEME MUSIC]

ALISON BEARD: So
first let me ask you,

why did you launch
Rolling Stone?

JANN WENNER: Well, I
was a rock and roll fan

and was not a very
good guitar player.

And I just wanted
to be a part of it.
I wanted to learn more about it.

I got consumed by the music,
and how it affected me,

and the message I
was getting from it.

And I just needed
to be a part of what

The Lovin' Spoonful called "the
magic that will set you free."

ALISON BEARD: And I
want to just clear it up
for people who don't know.

Did the name come from the old
proverb, Bob Dylan, The Rolling
Stones, all of the above?

JANN WENNER: All of the above,
but principally the Bob Dylan
song.

ALISON BEARD: And how
did you decide on it?

JANN WENNER: We kicked through
a bunch of different names,

and nothing really
sounded quite right.

I mean, remember it was the
sort of hippie psychedelic era,

so we were trying for kind
of quasi-psychedelic names.

Like, the groups had
names like the Jefferson

Airplane or the Grateful Dead
and sort of thinking of things
like--

I don't know-- The Electric
Tomato, or The Electric

Newspaper, or
something like that.

And finally, Rolling
Stone was a phrase

and a song that sort
of defined the times

and the things we
were thinking about.

And Ralph Gleason, my
co-founding partner,

wrote an essay for The American
Scholar called "Like a Rolling

Stone," in which he laid
out all of the themes and--

that we were going to
explore in the magazine,

the basic philosophical
underpinning of the magazine.
And rock and roll was important.

It carried serious social
and political messages,

that it was a kind of a
tribal telegraph, a glue that
held a generation together.

ALISON BEARD: And how did
you assemble your first group

of editors and
writers, the people who
really launched the thing?

JANN WENNER: Well, it was
really me and some volunteers,
whoever would work for free.
There were very few people.
ALISON BEARD: [LAUGHS]

JANN WENNER: It really
was me, and Ralph,
and the other editor.

There was a guy named Michael
Lydon who was a Newsweek Bureau

Chief who, at that time,
who could work part-time

at midnights, and
was a friend of mine.

And I think I got a college
buddy, Jonathan Cott,
to write in the first issue.

And somebody had been reading
in another fanzine called--
named Jon Landau to join me.

But it was all-- it was
just volunteers, free,

for the first--
almost first year.

ALISON BEARD: And at that point,
what was your ambition for it?

JANN WENNER: Just
to do something

very serious about
rock and roll,

and something that reflected
the changes that we saw.

And we had no particular
business plan of any kind.

Didn't know anything
about the business.
I was 21.

I had no idea whatsoever
about magazine distribution,

or advertising sales,
or financial management,

or planning, or forecasting,
or marketing, or zero.

ALISON BEARD: So how
did you figure that out?
How did you get readers?

JANN WENNER: Well, you
just learn on the job.

We found a magazine
distributor in San Francisco

at the last minute whose main
business was selling yachting
magazines and boat magazines.
ALISON BEARD: [LAUGHS]

JANN WENNER: The
distributor was sent out
to cities around the country.

We sent out 40,000
copies in boxes.

We got like 35,000
of them back--

unopened boxes
to-- they were sent

to distributors who never
ordered them, or didn't

ask for them, and
just sent out blind.
A few stuck out there.

And it got into a
few people's hands.

And we started getting
letters sent back

from people who had seen
it and wanted to see more.

There was enough letters--
like, I don't know,

20 or 30 letters-- to
say, oh, I'll keep going.

ALISON BEARD: And how
did you decide which
musicians and bands to feature?

Obviously, they were very
famous musicians at the time.

But, particularly, the
up-and-coming ones?

Like, how could
you and your team

predict what might
resonate with people?

JANN WENNER: Well,
we didn't try.
We just covered what we liked.

We didn't think about what
[? upcoming ?] and not.
There was no thought.
It was just what we liked.

And what we liked was John
Lennon and The Beatles.

And John Lennon was
on the first cover.

We didn't cover
what we didn't like.

We only covered what
was accessible to us.

The implication of
all your questions

here is there was some
kind of methodology,

or a premeditated
intent, or knowledge
that went into all of this.
[CHUCKLES] None.

It was completely on
the fly, spontaneous,

catch as catch can,
serendipity, other random acts

of chance, and
luck went into it.

ALISON BEARD: Yeah, and
in the book you describe
some early growing pains--

editorial differences
of opinion where

you had to step in
and say, no, this

is the direction I want
this magazine to go.

So talk to me a little
bit about that move

toward a little
bit more hierarchy,
or methodology, or a plan.

JANN WENNER: Well, I mean,
again, it was all intuitive.

I had my instincts and my ideas
about what the magazine should

be, and what it should stand
for, and what it should cover.

As I brought in other people
to help with it, including

by this time people
who were getting

paid and had some professional
experience, but still

again, very low on
the ladder people

willing to work for
$75 or $100 a week,

and quit some other job,
or didn't have another job.

Yeah, there were
differences of opinion.

And they were
passionately expressed.

I mean, in those days, everybody
was young, in their early 20s.

They were working for purposes
that they believed in,
for-- not really for money.

And if they disagreed with
me, then they would leave.

I felt very strong
about my vision.

My vision was that it was
the culture and the messages

that music carried in
it, and on the notions

and thoughts of people
like Bob Dylan, The Beatles
and The Stones.

They were expressing what the
yearnings of this generation
were.
ALISON BEARD: Yeah.

And I will say that
your descriptions

of those early
working environments--

there was a ton of drug
use [CHUCKLES] by yourself
and others in the magazine.

So how did you function
both personally

and as an organization
during that time?

It seems sort of
shocking in retrospect

that Rolling Stone
became such a success.

JANN WENNER: Well, the drug
use was off the premises.

But it wasn't a daily drug
[INAUDIBLE] by any means.

It was the recreation of
the time and that culture.

It didn't really bother anybody
or get in the way of anything.

I mean, a lot of time
was wasted in having fun.

But it didn't interfere
with any of our processes.

But also the idea of
having fun, of being happy,

infused both what we did
and what the message was,

which was not a
hedonistic have fun,
but a life should be happy.
Your work should also be fun.

You should be gratified and
fulfilled with your work.

If you're really
good at something

and you can do it well, and
in a way that's gratifying,

and what you're putting
out is helpful for people

and helpful to society,
then enjoy yourself.

ALISON BEARD: You
also identified

and worked with some
of the greatest writers
of the late 20th century--

Hunter Thompson, Tom
Wolfe, many others.

First, how did you know that
they were or would be great?
How did you spot them?

JANN WENNER: Well, they
were great to begin with.

[CHUCKLES] I mean, I read a book
of Hunter's about the Hell's

Angels and thought
he was terrific.

And I looked him up and
invited him to write for us.

And he did and right
from the beginning

was producing amazingly well
written, and funny, and precise
stuff.

Tom Wolfe, again, I was
a reader and a fan of his

when I was younger,
and in college,
and just out of college.

He had already been writing
for the New York Herald
Tribune and New York Magazine.

And I looked him up and
got him to write for us.
So I'd known of these writers.

They went on to produce their
best work at Rolling Stone,
for sure.

And I offered them the kind of
home, and place, and editing,

and space that they so wanted,
and so took advantage of--

and the kind of
topics and freedom
that really nurtured them.

ALISON BEARD: Yeah,
distinctive voice

seems to be something
that you looked for,

certainly identified,
and help them honed.

You know, but they are
big, creative egos, right?
JANN WENNER: Right.

ALISON BEARD: I think
genius comes with that.

So how did you pick
their assignments,

get them excited about
it, get them focused,

and then actually rein
them in with editing,

when obviously they were some
of the best in the world?

JANN WENNER: Well, I
mean, I think-- first off,

my experience is the best
talent is oftentimes the easiest

to work with, certainly
in the area of writers.
They are disciplined.
They have a vision.
They know what they want to do.

I think that part of
what you have to do

is find the right
things for them to do.

You need to help steer
them where they're
naturally inclined to go.

So I would understand, both
with Tom and with Hunter,

the kind of things
they're interested in,

the kind of thing that
sparked their passion,

the kind of topics they could
bring some of their insight to,

and just encourage
them along the way.

I mean, I didn't tell
them how to do anything.

You have to let them
do their own work.
It's just monitoring it.
It's like nudging it a little.
You don't do big abrupt moves.

I mean, the big abrupt
move is to pick out

your assignment is going
to be cover the election,
say, for Hunter.
With Tom it was--

his territory was American
culture, American society.

And so I said, write a
piece of fiction about

New York, knowing
New York was coming

alive at that particular
time when we commissioned
Bonfire of the Vanities.

And it's the classic novel
of New York at that time.
I don't know.

It's insight, [INAUDIBLE]
[? empathy, ?]

tolerance, humor, inspiration,
passion, patience.

ALISON BEARD: Yeah, I
bet a lot of patience.

So there weren't ever any
battles over cutting paragraphs
or changing headlines or--

JANN WENNER: No, no, no, again,
you don't want to intrude

on something they do-- if you're
good, like I was with Hunter,
I would--

I could Intuit what
he was planning to do
or where he was planning to go.
You didn't change much.

I mean, the biggest
issue with Hunter

was that he was always
writing on deadline,

and I knew how to edit
or finish his stuff

up when he didn't have
the time to do it.

I knew where he was going
and what he wanted to do.

JANN WENNER: Do you see--
because you followed

so many musicians
and their managers,

did you see parallels
in how musicians

were steered and
focused in a way that
made them more successful?
JANN WENNER: Yeah, I think so.
I mean, I think there's--

I think probably
one of my best gifts

was being able to understand
talent, and how it behaves,

and how to bring
the most out of it.

I mean, I really do have a good
understanding of what it takes

to make a record, and
what goes into it,

and [? then ?] kind
of the process even.

I could understand how
to manage creativity.

And I think that was one of the
most successful things I did,

both with the artists
that we covered

and with the writers
who worked for us.

ALISON BEARD: You
were fairly chummy

with all the big musicians
and record label heads?

Some might see that as
a conflict of interest.

How did you handle
it-- the fact that you
were covering your friends?

JANN WENNER: I mean, you
have to make decisions

according to your journalistic
instincts and your sense
of news.

We never shrank from
that, even when there

were some strong conflicts
when people didn't
want us to write about things.

But by and large, it was very
easy because nobody expected
anything different from us.
I mean, we started small.
We started independent.

We grew up as not being
part of that system.

Artists did not expect us
to give them favored record
views or slant anything.

Our value to them
and to the readers

was that we were independent,
that we had integrity.

And nobody ever questioned
that or acted in a way

as if we weren't going to
do what we intended to do,
what we didn't feel was right.

It was kind of the ground
rules that we established
with everybody and--

including people who became
my very close friends.

It rarely led to
any difficulties
because the people were artists.

They were people making
records, making music,

making life better for
people and for themselves.

These people were not
producing shoddy cars,

or digging up coal, or running
for office with real scrutiny
and investigation.

These were people
making records.
ALISON BEARD: Right.

As Rolling Stone grew and
expanded internationally,

how did you manage to sustain
the entrepreneurial rock

and roll culture and make
sure that it didn't become
too corporate or bureaucratic?

JANN WENNER: Well, first off,
it was a smallish business.

I mean, at our peak I think
we had 400 people or something
like that.

Secondly, I was always in
charge and quite clearly,
so I owned the joint.

So I could say what
was going to happen
and what wasn't going to happen.

Thirdly, there was a harmony
of purpose among the staff,

not in just the editors,
but the business people.

Everybody felt a sense
of common purpose.

So I had relatively little
politics and bureaucracy
to deal with.

Having said that, of course,
you can't tell everybody

all the time, but do you have
to enlist people's enthusiasm.

You have to lobby
for what you want.

You have to convince
people to go along

with it in the same manner
you would run anything.

You don't-- you really have
to be persuasive as well
as commanding.

It gets bureaucratic,
but, again, I

was capable of making
quick and fast decisions.
ALISON BEARD: Yeah.
And then did you--

you'd always been good at
spotting writing talent.

Were you also good at
spotting managerial talent?

JANN WENNER: Well, I
kind of was weak at that.

I mean, I was never
looking for somebody
to run it instead of me.

I was always looking for people
to manage it on my behalf.

So I didn't quite let
the reins go there.

We had some really good,
wonderful, hard-working people

on the business side in various
capacities for a long time.

But-- and also, I
just wasn't interested

in the rapid expansion
of the business.

So I guess I kept it in the
limits of what I could tolerate

rather than opening
up and saying,

OK, let me go find
a bunch of really

extraordinary, entrepreneurial,
hard-working people to run it.

ALISON BEARD: How do you think
your leadership style changed
over time?

You started at 21, [LAUGHS]
and then managed it
into your late middle age.
JANN WENNER: I guess I grew up.

I got a little less mercurial,
more thoughtful steady.
I learned to delegate more--
the typical things you do.

I learned that once you
start yelling at people,

you've already
lost your argument.
So--
[LAUGHTER]

ALISON BEARD: I'll
need to remember
that with my teenage children.
[LAUGHS]

JANN WENNER: [INAUDIBLE]
it's the same thing, though--
ALISON BEARD: Yeah.

JANN WENNER: --exactly
the same thing.

If you start yelling
at teenagers,

they've already
got you, you know?

[CHUCKLES] They-- it
doesn't work there, either.

I-- my manager style was
kind of trying to inspire
people to do their best.
I think that was very tough.

I wanted people to do a good
job and do their best job.

And if they do that, I
didn't care about the rest.

I didn't care what the days
they were working, or hours,

or too much how they got
about it-- just do your best,

and be happy, and
enjoy yourself.

Give me your best-- that's
what I demanded of people.
And if I didn't--

if they weren't
doing their best--

they were lazy-- then
I would let them go.
ALISON BEARD: Yeah.

From the beginning,
the magazine made

a point of covering
politics very rigorously as
much as music.
Why did you make that decision?

JANN WENNER: Well, I was
raised in a political family.

My parents were both
active Democrats.

So I grew up with politics,
and I love politics.

And it just became
a passion of mine.

The other reason was that
the whole initial concept

of Rolling Stone
was that music was

a voice for social
and political change.

ALISON BEARD: Let's also talk
about environmental journalism.

You had a lot of coverage
at Rolling Stone.

There was a short-lived
magazine called Earth Times.
You found it outside.

Why did you put such
a priority on covering

the environment and especially
the climate crisis earlier
than so many others?

JANN WENNER: Well, again,
I think it probably

has to do with the sensitivities
of a generation that grew up

with the promise of the
Declaration of Independence--

of life, liberty, and
the pursuit of happiness.

And within that is this definite
love of the natural world

and nature and not despoiling
the countryside around you,

not exploiting all the
stuff, that living cleanly
on the Earth is part of life.
It's part of your liberty.

It's part of the
pursuit of happiness--

a clean environment, a
place to live that is safe.
And we saw this endangered.

1970, I think, was
the first Earth Day
when we were three years old.
And we were very aware of this.

We were also on the
West Coast, which

was the home of a
lot of conservation
societies and the Sierra Club.

But it became apparent this
was our responsibility.

It was a part of our
awareness, part of our cause.
And it just came naturally.
ALISON BEARD: Yeah.

So among your many
accomplishments,

you also started the Rock
and Roll Hall of Fame.

In your view, what is the
most important criteria
for induction?

JANN WENNER: Well,
I think that it

has to do with creating
a body of work that's

important and essential,
that's influential,

that is original, a real
excellence in what you do,

a real originality, and that you
make important lasting music.

I mean, it's an award
for creative excellence.

ALISON BEARD: And, again, were
there any battles or concerns

over that when you were part
of the nominating committee,

or friends who got
upset that they
weren't inducted quick enough?

JANN WENNER: Well,
I know there are

people who are upset
that weren't inducted.

Very few of them have
expressed that to me.

There were lots of
battles because the people

that are passionate about it--
the critics, the music fans--

everybody has their fav-- after
about for the first 10 or 15

years, it was very obvious
who should get inducted.

And it's just differences
of taste, and opinion,

and personal preference,
and what you grew up with,
and what you love.

And every single person
brought so much passion to it.

And many years, for many artists
there is obvious agreement on--

of course, Ray
Charles; of course,
this person belongs to that.

But then as the years went on,
as the talent and the styles
got more diverse, it became--

everybody, again, had their
separate different passions

and the artists
they were fans of.

And so the unanimity of
choice got less and less.
But, again, I think--
the thing is everybody--

It's just a matter of just
passion and different tastes.
I mean, it's all legitimate.
ALISON BEARD: Mm.

Yeah, and as music
became more diverse,

your taste, as you said,
the founding group's tastes
were squarely rock and roll.

So how did you make sure that
the magazine and then the Hall

of Fame acknowledged
other genres--
country, rap, hip hop?

JANN WENNER: Well, as
it got into more recent

in the last 10 or 15 years and
it became more pop, especially

hip hop and other kinds
of new forms of music,

you just simply have to get
younger people involved--

people who are more sympathetic
and grew up with that music.

Really, the people who
are being inducted now

are not people I really
am that familiar with.

I mean, I know who
they are, but I'm not
familiar with their music.

I don't sit in
judgment on it anymore
or make those decisions.

But there's a
committee of people

that keeps being
refreshed with people

who are more contemporary and
the same with the magazine.

I didn't-- wasn't that deep into
the music of the last 20 years
or so.

But the music staff was
younger and more on top of it.

And I just basically
trusted their judgment,

and also had enough judgment to
know if their judgment was good
or not.

ALISON BEARD:
[LAUGHS] I like that.

So, in the memoir,
you also talk in-depth
about your personal life.

And in particular, you
coming out publicly
as a gay man in middle age.
JANN WENNER: Mm-hmm.

ALISON BEARD: How did
that decision play out
in your professional life?

How did you tell
your colleagues?

And do you feel like
there was a shift at work

once you were able to be a
more authentic person there?

JANN WENNER: Well, I
didn't tell my colleagues.

It kind of got around
on the gossip mill.

And there was some stuff in
some of the local newspapers
about it.

But it didn't change
anything at all, not a bit.

The business, my relationships
with my colleagues,

my leader-- it changed
nothing, neither
professionally nor personally.

The people who are
my best friends then,

the creative milieu,
remain the same.
Not a thing changed.
Isn't that interesting?
ALISON BEARD: Yeah.

So do you wish that you
had done it earlier?

JANN WENNER: No, I don't because
I had a very happy marriage
up and to a point.

And I had three kids,
and I loved that life.

And that life-- during that
time, the first 25 years
[INAUDIBLE], it was great.
I wouldn't change it at all.

ALISON BEARD: And
then you fell in love.

JANN WENNER: And then
I fell in love, which--

unexpectedly, and
then you go with that.

And then I have three more
kids [CHUCKLES] on top of it.

I see them all of them from
ages 37 to 14 all the time.

ALISON BEARD: And one
of your older children

is-- became very active
in Rolling Stone, right?
So how did you manage that?

JANN WENNER: Well, my
30-year-old son [INAUDIBLE]

came to work for me right after
he graduated from college,

I didn't expect he was
going to end up taking over,

but as it happens, we worked
together really closely
for four or five years.

He got the knowledge
and the training
of what the magazine was about.
And he sat in on my meetings.

And it became clear that he
had the talent and the aptitude
to take it over.

And when we sold the
magazine, he did the sale.

And he went with the magazine,
and they put him on a contract

and they just
renewed his contract.

And he's the--
although he doesn't--

he has a piece of it, still,
he is the CEO of the company.
He just worked his way up.

And the biggest issue is
getting me out of there.

I still thought, well, even
though he's running things,

I get to be in charge and say
what everything is going to be.
ALISON BEARD: [LAUGHS]

JANN WENNER: No,
no, no, [INAUDIBLE]
he has ideas about it.
And he politely and--
eased me out.

[LAUGHS] He was not even telling
me that it was time to go.
I had to read it myself.

And I finally said, "Look,
Gus, just tell me the truth.
What do you want me to do?"
"Well, nothing."
[LAUGHTER]
It was right.

After 50 years, you
have a hard time letting

go of being in charge,
especially of something you

built yourself,
and it's your baby.

You have a deep
attachment to it.
It's your pride, your joy.
ALISON BEARD: Hmm.

And what do you hope
that your legacy will be,

both for the magazine industry
and the music industry?

JANN WENNER: Well, I think that
in addition to having put out--

being a really good
editor, and sponsor,

and discovered a lot
of talent, and having

promoted and advocated
and proselytized

for one of America's
greatest art forms,
which is rock and roll.

We also have made
a difference, have

made a consequential
contribution

to society and to progress,
to what the nation stands

for and looks for, what
people are going to do--

that somehow we
furthered human justice.
ALISON BEARD: Terrific.

Well, thank you so
much for your time.
Again, the book is terrific.

It was really a pleasure
speaking with you.

JANN WENNER: Thank
you very much.
[THEME MUSIC]

ALISON BEARD: That was
Jann Wenner, founder

and longtime editor and
publisher of Rolling Stone.

His new memoir, Like a
Rolling Stone, is out now,

and more of our
conversation can be

found in the
November/December magazine,
and in a few weeks on hbr.org.

If you liked today's episode,
we have more podcasts

to help you manage
yourself, your team,
and your organization.

Find them at hbr.org/podcasts
or search HBR in Apple Podcasts,
Spotify, or wherever you listen.
